answers.answer: I would say not but the details are not complete, such as symptoms etc.70% is the usual for stenting, or greater. Also the right artery can get away with more than the left.
I just noticed it says right dominant. This does change things a bit, but if there are no symptoms I would still say a definite no.

I'm not a health professional so keep that in mind with my post.  In my opinion, a 70% blockage will need either a stent or bypass sooner than later.  It's the old 'blocked water pipe' analogy, a dirty pipe will eventually plug up.Needless to say, when you have a 70% blockage, you need to keep the junk in your blood under control and keep your arteries as healthy as possible.  If you smoke, stop.  Keep your blood pressure under control.  Certainly you need to exercise, and if you are overweight, losing weight will help greatly.  Diabetes is a huge risk. Taking good drugs like a statin and blood pressure meds is also very important.Over a period of years, I had eight stents inserted.  In almost all cases I received a stent when the blockage was above 80%, I have to say that blockages of 40 - 70% always were eventually treated.  I had heart bypass surgery with two 60% blockages, but these blockages were in dangerous locations (arterial branches) and I was experiencing daily angina.Everyone's situation is different.  You are smart to learn as much as you can.  If you send a followup post with more information about your condition, you will probably get excellent ideas that will help you.

question: RCA, dominant, proximal 50%, mid 70% narrowing.  Does this warrant an angioplasty.
title: is angioplasty required
